dose-response-analysis

Source: vignettes/dose-response-analysis.Rmd
dose-response-analysis.Rmd



library(batchCurve)

Accepted assay format

Accepted formats include a 10 point serial dilution of 2-3 replicates in either 96 or 384 well plates. The exact format will dictate how many positions (pos_x) are available on the plate. The available positions for each format are shown below:

96 well layout options.
384 well layout options.

batchCurve comes bundled with a number of example dose-response sample files:

# lists the names of available example data files
batchCurve_example()
#>  [1] "compare_results.csv"  "example_meta.csv"     "example1_data.csv"   
#>  [4] "example1_results.csv" "plan_IC50s.csv"       "TRno0000.CSV"        
#>  [7] "TRno0001.CSV"         "TRno0002.CSV"         "TRno0003.CSV"        
#> [10] "TRno3735.CSV"         "TRno3965.CSV"         "TRno4849.CSV"        
#> [13] "TRno4850.CSV"

Meta data requirments

Example_meta.csv contains the meta data that describe the assays and plate contents, here one row represent one assay:

  • Plate ID variable to link meta with the plate file of raw measurements
  • Location data describing the format and positions on the plate each assay sits
  • Treatment and cell ID information
  • Dose range information
f <- batchCurve_example("example_meta.csv")
f

plate_id

position_id

NITD609

Dd2

0.04

2

  • The column names of the meta file rely of exact text matching, so its best to work from a template file.

  • All assays on the same plate must be setup with the same number of replicates, but formats between plates in the same batch can be different, i.e the meta could include a 384 well plate in triplicate containing 10 assays as well as a 96 well plate in duplicate containing 3 assays.

  • You can filter the meta data if you wish to exclude certain assays.

Raw data format requirements

The analysis pipeline was developed to be compatible with an Omega Fluostar plate reader csv output (ASCII), which includes 3 required components:

  1. Data stored in files with a prefix - â€˜TRnoâ€™ or â€˜automatedâ€™.
#look at one of the raw data file examples
f <- batchCurve_example("TRno3735.CSV")
  1. An ID variable set when reading the plate which matches the plate_id in the meta file (Omega prefixes with â€˜ID1:â€™). This should be in row 3 column 1 of raw data csv and must match exactly you meta file plate_ID name.
#batchCurve looks in row 3 column 1 for ID variable
utils::read.csv(f, nrow = 3, header = FALSE)[3,1]
#> [1] "ID1: plate_A3"
  1. Raw read data in plate format where well A01 begins in row 10, column 1 of the file.
# showing file from row 9
head(utils::read.csv(f, skip = 8),11)
#>   Chromatic..1   X X.1  X.2  X.3  X.4  X.5  X.6  X.7  X.8  X.9 X.10
#> 1     Cycle: 1  NA  NA   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA   NA
#> 2          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737  746  512
#> 3          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737 6997  512
#> 4          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737 5973  485
#> 5          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737 6997  516
#> 6          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737 5973  517
#> 7          696 702 785 1474 2633 4078 5928 6064 6246 6965 6997  524
#> 8          636 621 714 1336 2365 3731 5050 6085 6065 5927 5973  483
#> 9          341 574 598  600  626  666  705  708  722  737  746  512

Usage

To fit curves to a batch of raw data, you need to supply the fit_data() function with the meta file. This can either be with the file path or by setting the working directory to where the data lives. If no path is supplied the function assumes all data is in the working directory. All output/results are exported to the same directory as the meta file.

In addition, the user can supply the function with a text batch_id, this is used to prefix the output file names. This is advisable to avoid accumulating result files with the same name and makes searching results easier, particularity if analysis is run a second time on a filtered meta file.

#use example files
meta <- batchCurve_example("example_meta.csv")

l <- fit_data(file_path = meta, prefix = 'example1')

This function will provide some console feedback on the analysis progress. Once complete, two objects are exported to csv file and also returned in a list. note: The first assay in the example data set is artificial and designed to fail fitting!

  1. A prefix_results.csvâ€™ file containing the meta data and model coefficient columns appended. This data frame is also returned as the first item in a list for further analysis, here each row still represents 1 assay. A unique identifier (IC50_key) is assigned to avoid clashes between repeat assays and link to the assay data.
m <- l[[1]]
head(m, 10)[,c(1,6,8,13,20)]
#>          IC50_key index cell                 IC50 hill_slope
#> 1  IirE0wRkfPLjf5   C05  Dd2               Failed         NA
#> 14 r4q6UFgAxJMtp6   C06  Dd2    0.397087567384264   1.673443
#> 11 4zbAu2aEuohDjD   C04  Dd2    0.409200699062012   3.917486
#> 12 SKZFSuyotalziD   C04  3D7    0.609087279032902   4.360740
#> 5  5pb90SUHjlsA2J   C01  Dd2  0.00183920429016226   2.970942
#> 2  OCP3OyHgjCyj3W   C01  Dd2    0.001979863848655   6.139312
#> 3  hg1DIdTQhwBDgU   C01  Dd2  0.00199157050920151   5.418731
#> 4  de5llzyOSJAWUm   C02  Dd2   0.0118873520155513   2.471598
#> 9  Ci4LpGZKaBwXXH   C02  Dd2   0.0120119550447347   2.119453
#> 6  RN1SO1NYrNWbGH   C03  Dd2 0.000860595386861181   6.341140
  1. Normalised measurements and dose in uM are exported and the unique IC50_key links it back to the assay coefficients data frame.
d <- l[[2]]
head(d, 10)
#>               key        dose replicate_1 replicate_2 replicate_3
#> 1  IirE0wRkfPLjf5 10.00000000      100.00       96.41       98.77
#> 2  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  5.00000000      100.00       96.41       98.77
#> 3  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  2.50000000      100.00       96.41       98.77
#> 4  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  1.25000000      100.00       96.41       98.77
#> 5  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.62500000        3.15        3.15        3.15
#> 6  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.31250000        3.15        3.15        3.15
#> 7  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.15625000        3.15        3.15        3.15
#> 8  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.07812500       96.41       96.41       96.41
#> 9  IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.03906250       96.41       96.41       96.41
#> 10 IirE0wRkfPLjf5  0.01953125       96.41       96.41       96.41

Quality Control

The standard Hill model enables generating sigmoidal curves that capture dose-response data in most cases. However, this is not appropriate in cases with multiple points of inflection, i.e multiphasic data. It is important for users to visually assess both the assay quality and the fit quality of their data before accepting an IC50 value.

A separate function for plotting the data and models is included in batchCurve, plot_fit(). This functionality is separated from the model fitting procedure to allow the user the option to re-plot the results after some manipulation, i.e you want to filter some failed assays out or merge multiple batches together.

See vignette("visualise models") for a walk through of this procedure.
